annotation.TEXT: To be honest, I've actually heard of and seen a few attempts to remake the DOS games before. As far as I know, none of them managed to see it through (with the exception of this game). It's kind of a shame in some ways, since the idea of remaking the DOS games could actually be a decent concept if given to the right people. This game, on the other hand...doesn't quite fit into those regards.

Blade Man follows a much more predetermined pattern than Dyna Man. He'll stick to one side of the screen and toss out several arcing blades that are easy enough to avoid. When the piston in the middle of the room is high enough, he'll jump to the center and start throwing blades directly at you, then jump back to his previous position. Wash, rinse, repeat.

With that being said however, it does have its uses (even if they are few and far between). Aside from blowing up doors, it can be used to take out shielded enemies and a few other ones set in irritating places. The main downside is that you need to carefully aim this thing, otherwise it'll only amount to wasting your time. Factor in that it also has an extremely low ammo count, and you're looking at a very frustrating weapon to use properly.

The room you're seeing here is one of two possible paths in this stage. It's probably the more difficult of the routes, but a bit more direct in terms of reaching the boss. It also happens to hold a unique item as well...
...Really? Could you have not moved that over just a tiny bit?
Just to note: The open lava in this area is actually a pit. Getting knocked into it will send you through it, rather than landing slightly on top of it as you would with spikes.

Trust me, you'll want to take out most of those Metools before going any further (unless you like facing bullet hell while jumping across platforms), especially if you want to reach that "W." Yes, there are letters in this game. There are only four of them this time around, and collecting them all opens up a "hidden stage" of sorts (you'll see later as to why I put that in quotes).

Sonic Reflector is actually rather lackluster in this game compared to the original (at least there it was good for the occasional enemy that was too low to hit with the buster). The only thing it has going for it here is its high ammo count. Beyond that, it's incredibly weak, and its bouncing mechanic tends to be more unreliable if anything.

Razor Blade is actually one of the better weapons in the game (and is far superior to the one found in Super Mega Man 3). While it doesn't deal that much damage, it's the only weapon in the game that has any kind of decent vertical range. It also has a rather high ammo count, so you can easily abuse it to hit enemies that are generally out of your reach. The keyword here being "generally" (the arc on this thing is rather tight, so there's a few enemies you likely won't be able to hit even with proper positioning).

Another badly implemented aspect of this game comes from the boss fights. Dyna Man, sadly, follows roughly the same simple pattern he did in the original game. He jumps around like an imbecile and tosses out small explosives at you. Despite following a predictable pattern, he can actually kill you very quickly considering his damage output is absurdly high (much like every other boss in this game).
Nice animation, bro.

Although I should have mentioned this before, now seems like the best time to do so: A good portion of the stages in this game actually have alternate paths. However, these aren't exactly optional or branching pathways that are off to the side. Certain portions of levels actually change slightly once you beat them, or if you happen to beat another specific Robot Master first (the border around the RM's mug-shots will change slightly if a stage's alternate path has opened).

A few days ago, someone brought this particular game to my attention. This is "Mega Man DOS: The Remake," as I'm going to call it. It was recently released on a sub-reddit forum, and as the title obviously implies, it's meant to be a recreation and improvement of both Mega Man DOS games (consider yourself lucky if you haven't heard of them up until this point).

For as decent as his stage was, Sonic Man himself is a bit of a letdown. Much like Blade Man, he follows a predetermined path of jumping to one of a few set locations, taking the time to fire projectiles at you, and then repeating the process again. The only difference here is the magnet in the center of the screen, which will actually let you reach him when he jumps to the higher platforms. Beyond that, this is a rather dull fight (especially if you have the Razor Blade).

As you've probably noticed by now, the screen scrolling is also a bit off. I honestly don't know why it's so delayed and slow (especially considering there are some specific rooms in this game that have incredibly fast scrolling, but they're few and far between).

For all the issues I've listed with this game so far, I do have to give credit for this in particular: Indicators as to where yoku blocks are going to emerge. It makes any sections involving them far more manageable (and trust me, some of the sections that include them would be downright evil without these indicators).

The weapon set in this game is yet another letdown. Most of them are bland projectiles that have little variation or don't do that much damage, effectively making them useless outside of boss battles. Dynamo Wrecker is a bit different in these regards, but even then, it still manages to be one of the worst weapons in the game. It bounces after being fired out and sticks to any surface it hits. The bomb itself can't hurt enemies, and the explosion it produces is very small.

Yes, the game actually does have loading screens like this (and it even has a mock-up version of DOS when you start up the game). In any case, let's do a run-down of the basics: This game follows MM3 mechanics, which means the only thing Mega Man can't do is charge his buster. Speaking of which, Mega Man himself controls very strangely in this game. Hell, the whole game engine is whacked-out, for that matter.

For one, everything in this game feels floaty and rather disjointed. It's kind of hard to explain, but Mega Man himself doesn't feel quite right in terms of maneuvering. I think it mostly has to do with some of the awkward, if minor quirks that you'll probably notice as you play this (such as the fact that you can't detach yourself from a ladder unless you push jump and either left or right, not just the jump button on its own).

Sonic Man's stage actually has a rather interesting gimmick: Magnets embedded in surfaces that cause you to jump higher or lower. Although my memory is a bit fuzzy, I could have sworn I've seen the exact same graphics for these magnets before (it could be from one of the Game Boy games, but I'm not too sure at this point).

Uhh...Don't ask me. As far as I can tell, this is probably an easter egg of sorts (considering "Alsnaps" is a name in the credits of this game). I have no idea if there's any others like this, but either way, it doesn't seem to do anything.

Don't be surprised if you get hit by the Picket Man's metal blades while going through this (suddenly fast) screen transition. Enemy projectiles can actually pass through transitions with you at times, potentially resulting in unavoidable damage.
